Award.AwardTitle: Santa Fe Conference on Rock Magnetism
Award.AbstractNarration:
Rapid advances in research on magnetism and magnetic materials are occurring in geophysics, geochemistry, nanoscience, condensed-matter physics, and to a great extent, along the boundaries between these fields. An interdisciplinary discussion of critical developments in the geoscience applications of fine-particle magnetism, and their fundamental physical foundations, will help to advance our understanding of Earth's surface environment and its deep interior. This award will provide partial support to hold a Conference on Rock Magnetism and its Applications, June 26-29, 2014 in Santa Fe NM, continuing a biennial series of such conferences. St. John's
College will serve as the venue. Support will help cover the facility-use costs and to provide partial coverage of participant travel expenses (full coverage for invited plenary speakers and on-campus accommodations for other participants).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Organized by the faculty and staff of the University of Minnesota’s Institute for Rock Magnetism, the 10th Biennial Santa Fe Conference on Rock Magnetism was held June 26-29 2014 on the campus of St. John’s College in Santa Fe, New Mexico, and was attended by fifty US and international scientists as well as graduate students. The broad goal of the Santa Fe Conference series is to bring together present and future leaders in rock magnetism, paleomagnetism and related fields for in-depth discussion of fundamental aspects of rock and mineral magnetism, as well as applications in global geophysics, tectonics, extraterrestrial magnetism, and surficial environmental studies.  These meetings are designed to allow collaborative exploration of the state of the art in magnetic geophysics and its applications throughout the natural sciences  (including environmental science, geobiology, mineral physics and others), in an informal, interactive discussion-oriented mode. Ultimately the purpose is to advance our ability to understand the evolution of the Earth's deep interior and its surface environments, by analyzing the information stored in the magnetically-ordered iron minerals contained in rocks and sediments.

   Frontier research areas covered in the 2014 conference included: (1) Magnetism of the oceanic lithosphere;  (2) Chemical alteration and remagnetization; (3) Magnetic anisotropy and the fabrics of rocks and sediments, and (4) Fundamental rock magnetism: Problems and opportunities. Besides the technical sessions, a one day specialized workshop was held to discuss a technique referred to as first order reversal curves, one of the most broadly useful developments in the rock magnetic community in the last twenty years, but one of the most difficult characterization tools to grasp owing to its inherent computational intensity The workshop was organized in order to make this tool more accessible to the rock magnetic community and promote the adaptation of best practices. Leading scientists in the development of processing code and techniques presented seminars highlighting developments, applications, techniques and data interpretation.

   Each of these research areas is the subject of sustained and intensive study by research groups around the world. Naturally, the ultimate solutions to the problems outlined above still remain to be discovered, but it is focused gatherings of leading international and interdisciplinary researchers and students that constitute a very important part of the process of discovery. In this context, the Santa Fe Conference helps advance the state of the art in magnetic geophysics and its Earth-science applications.
